metadata.title: Microplastics and nanoplastics: would they affect global biodiversity change?

sections.text: Keywords Biodiversity change .Microplastics . Nanoplastics . Microbial community . Environmental concerns

sections.heading: Concerns of micro(nano)plastics
sections.text:
Today, plastic products are used in all walks of life, such as medical equipment, construction, personal care products, household goods, and child toys. As plastic products are bringing convenience to social life, the negative side of Bplastic age^ is gradually emerging (Geyer et al. 2017). Due to the low recycling rate and mismanagement, a large number of waste plastics have been released continuously into the environment. Plastic products could be gradually decomposed and fragmented in the environment under the condition of weathering, ultraviolet radiation, and biodegradation, forming microplastics (< 5 mm) and nanoplastics (< 100 nm) (Song et al. 2018). Evidences showed that, as compared with the
easy and fast process of large plastic fragments turning into microplastics, the decomposition of microplastics to smaller particles for mineralization is extremely hard and slow (Andrady 2011), which was presumed to be hundreds to thousands of years (Barnes et al. 2009). This may cause the continuous presence of microplastics and nanoplastics in the environment, seemingly difficult to be removed in short-term, and becoming a Blong-term^ and Bpersistent^ global problem. Most scientists firmly believe that establishing laws and regulation by governments could help to reduce or even control this pollution. Although the consensus control standards of plastics have not yet been made, some attempts to reduce their production and consumption, like banning the distribution and/or sale of plastic and banning the use of plastic microbeads in personal care or cosmetics, have been performed in some countries, such as the UK (Department for Environment 2016, 2018), the USA (Mcdevitt et al. 2017), New Zealand (Ministry for the Environment 2018), and the United Nations (UN Environment 2018).
Micro(nano)plastics were widely found in soils (Zhang and Liu 2018), oceans (Law and Thompson 2014), river waters (Anderson et al. 2017; Hu et al. 2019; Su et al. 2016), air (Gasperi et al. 2018), bottled water (Oßmann et al. 2018), sediments (Munari et al. 2017; Zhao et al. 2018), and municipal wastewater (Ziajahromi et al. 2017) (Fig. 1). micro(nano)plastics to be estimated if they migrate and transport among different media. The complexity of environmental matrixes and the small particle size of micro(nano)plastic have caused the lacking of efficient and standard technologies for their determination and analysis, especially nanoplastics. These challenges have limited the acquisition of information on the release, migration, and environmental occurrence of micro(nano)plastics. Recent investigations reported that microplastics were measured in bottle water as 2649 ± 2857 L−1 (Oßmann et al. 2018), determined in sediments as 123.6 items kg−1 of dry weight (Zhao et al. 2018), detected in sewage sludge as 22.7 ± 12.1 × 103 particles kg−1 dry sludge (Li et al. 2018), found in farming land as 7100–42,900 particles kg−1 soil (Zhang and Liu 2018), respectively. Although microplastic and nanoplastic concentrations remain at low levels in the environment, they have potential risks to the environment if the plastic pollution is out of control. Therefore, the fate of micro(nano)plastics in the environment still needs to be explored.
As the production and consumption of plastics keep increasing globally, the mass and rate of micro(nano)plastics released are increased continuously. The adverse impact of micro(nano)plastics on global biodiversity has gradually emerged. Global biodiversity includes terrestrial biodiversity and marine biodiversity, that is, referring to the variety and variability of life on Earth. Biodiversity typically measures variation at the genetic, species, and ecosystem level (Eser 2010). The major impact factors influencing biodiversity are considered mainly due to human activities including global
warming, human overpopulation, hybridization, genetic pollution/erosion and food security, overexploitation, habitat destruction, and invasive species. Microplastics and nanoplastics are results of human activities. Because of their small particle size, micro(nano)plastics can be directly or indirectly taken in by many kinds of fish (Steer et al. 2017; Wang et al. 2019), zoobenthos (Cauwenberghe and Janssen 2014; Li et al. 2016), seabirds (Holland et al. 2016; Reynolds and Ryan 2018), and marine mammals (Hernandez-Gonzalez et al. 2017; Rebolledo et al. 2013), especially the filter-feeding animals (Germanov et al. 2018). The digestive system of feeders could possibly be physically blocked after accidental ingestion of micro(nano)plastics, which may induce damage to the digestive system, reducing nutrient uptake, or even cause death (Provencher et al. 2010). Research results indicated that polystyrene (PS) nanoplastics (39.4 nm) passed through the cell membrane into the surrounding tissues, blood, and circulatory system, even into the brains of medaka, and they were difficult of being gotten rid (Kashiwada 2006). Additionally, micro(nano)plastics can be bioaccumulated and transferred through the food chain (Diepens and Koelmans 2018; Setälä et al. 2014). Furthermore, micro(nano)plastic can be served as a vector for organisms, taking them from one location to another (Hartmann et al. 2017). Once a suitable habitat is invaded by the alien organisms, they would grow explosively, forming biological invasion, and severely impair the local biodiversity, as well as the ecological balance. Moreover, Fu et al. (2018) indicated that the presence of 0.2 g/L of PS microplastics inhibited
methane production and changed microbial community structure, but the mechanisms were not identified.
Based on the mentioned above, it would be worth assessing the impacts of micro(nano)plastics on global biodiversity; however, how can we do it? Do we need to study a case by one for micro(nano)plastics and then simply try to prove the impacts on the biodiversity? Or dowe need to understand their mechanisms of environmental migration and occurrence, fate, their effects on health and ecological, and as a vector for organisms? Clearly, the latter is more reasonable than the former and is still to be explored in the future. Accordingly, source control of micro(nano)plastic would be an effective method to nip the bud at its renaissance.
Effect of micro(nano)plastics on growth and reproduction
Micro(nano)plastics could be considered as one of the factors affecting biological growth and reproduction, as the growth, development, and reproductive toxicity of living organisms by micro(nano)plastics have been revealed (Sussarellu et al. 2016). Smaller microplastic particles can be easily taken in and accumulated by organisms. Evidences have demonstrated that the impacts of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) microplastics on growth, oxidative damage, oviposition, and biological enzyme activity of gilthead seabream (Sparus aurata) have been observed (Espinosa et al. 2017). However, the dosage (500 mg kg−1 of PVCmicroplastics for 30 days) was extremely high and cannot occur in the environment.
Evidences showed that PS microplastics could obviously reduce the number and size of egg cells, sperm motility, and larval number for oyster at 0.023 mg L−1 (2–6 μm) (Sussarellu et al. 2016), and pose a significant growth reduction for Gammarus pulex at concentration from 10 to 40% (mass concentration, microplastics/sediment, 20–500 μm) (RedondoHasselerharm et al. 2018). PS nanoplastics could decrease the filter-feeding rate of blue mussel (Mytilus edulis L.) at 0.3 g L−1 (30 nm) and show a greater impact on the cellular and organizational levels (Wegner et al. 2012). Reproduction limitation of earthworms by microplastics and the vegetative and reproductive growth inhibition of wheat have been confirmed (Huerta et al. 2016). Microplastics would also cause energy and lipid metabolism disorders and oxidative stress in mice (Deng et al. 2017). Besides, micro(nano)plastics can increase the permeability of sediments, changing the heat transfer, hence affecting the temperature-related biological development and growth processes. For instance, changes in temperature would affect the sex ratio of the turtle eggs during incubation (Carson et al. 2011).
PS nanoplastics can readily cross lipid membranes, changing the cell membrane structure and membrane protein activity, weakening the diffusion rate of molecules so as to change
cell functions (Rossi et al. 2014). A research performed by Lundqvist et al. (2008) used six different PS nanoparticles (three different surface chemistries (carboxyl-modified, amine-modified, and plain PS) and two sizes of each (50 nm and 100 nm)) to test the interaction between PS nanoplastics and proteins, and the results showed that the formation of coronal protein rings on the surface of nanoplastics significantly affected on the endocytosis of nanoplastics (Lundqvist et al. 2008). Additionally, PS nanoplastics (39.4 nm) can penetrate the blood-brain barrier, a highly selective barrier, into the brain tissues, which may become a potential threat to organisms (Kashiwada 2006). PS nanoplastics (70 nm, 20 μg L−1) could significantly change the movement of zebrafish larvae, and enter the circulatory system through intestinal tissues, resulting in local infection and lipid accumulation in the liver, causing disorders of liver function and energy metabolism (Lu et al. 2016a, b). PS nanoplastics (20 nm) can be adsorbed on the surface of crescent algae, chlorella, and grid algae by electrostatic effect, which hinders the absorption and utilization of carbon dioxide and photons by algae cells, reducing the photosynthetic efficiency and limiting the growth of algae (Bhattacharya et al. 2010; Nolte et al. 2017). Additionally, compared with the negatively charged PS nanoplastics, the positively charged PS nanoplastics can greatly increase the content of reactive oxygen species and free calcium ions, simultaneously decreasing the mitochondrial membrane potential and content of adenosine triphosphate in cells, thus affecting the activity and proliferation of cells (Bhattacharjee et al. 2014). If normal survival, growth, and reproduction of species are arrested, the service function of species and ecosystem may reduce and global biodiversity change might happen. Although the growth, development, and reproductive toxicity of living organisms by micro(nano)plastics have been revealed, above tests were carried out using high or extremely high dosage of micro(nano)plastics within a short period. More tests are needed to examine the impacts of lower dosage or environmental dosage and long-term exposure tomicro(nano)plastics. Moreover, to date, most research on toxicity and risk assessments of micro(nano)plastics were performed using PS materials. We expect that more research is needed using other micro(nano)plastic materials such as PVC, polyethylene (PE), polypropylene (PP), and polyethylene terephthalate (PET).
Changes in microbial communities caused by micro(nano)plastics
Research on microbial community showed that the presence ofmicroplastics could increase the effect of treated wastewater on a freshwater microbial community (Eckert et al. 2017). Increasing the content of microplastics could evidently
enhance the spawning density of Halobates sericeus and the predation of eggs and larvae could speed up the energy transfer among different communities, thereby affecting and changing the structure and composition of the microbial community (Goldstein et al. 2012). Changes of the biological community structure affected by microplastics accumulating in pelagic waters have been revealed, especially the reproductive enhancement of pathogenic bacteria (Eckert et al. 2017). Water biological community could be changed after exposed to microplastics (PE, PP, and PS), and microplastics host distinguishable bacterial community (Ogonowski et al. 2018). Meanwhile, the profiles of the bacterial and fungal community were obviously associated with the profiles of microplastics (Ogonowski et al. 2018). Soil biological community structure, composition, and function can be obviously altered with the existence of biodegradable plastics, mainly through increasing soil temperature, reducing gas exchange, and decreasing sunlight transmissivity; at the same time, enrichment of fungal taxa and the microbial activity were significantly enhanced, while the population of soil invertebrates was decreased (Bandopadhyay et al. 2018). Moreover, as a barrier, soil physical structure can be changed bymicroplastic mulches (7%,w/ w) (Liu et al. 2017) so as to affect root development and the exudation of plants (Wang et al. 2016).
Ecological impact of micro(nano)plastics as a multicarrier
Due to large specific surface area, strong hydrophobic surface, and high diffusion capacity, micro(nano)plastics have been proved to be a new type of biological and chemical vector ( K o e lm a n s e t a l . 2 0 1 6 ; S h e n e t a l . 2 0 1 9 ) . Micro(nano)plastics can enrich organic and inorganic pollutants and also are good habitat for bacteria and algae. The coexistence of micro(nano)plastics and pollutants would promote the accumulation of pollutants in living organisms and alter the toxic effects andmechanism. PS nanoplastics (50 nm) could significantly increase the concentration of phenanthrene in fleas and showed additive toxic effects with phenanthrene (Ma et al. 2016). The authors further reported that nanoplastics could inhibit the degradation of phenanthrene and its metabolites, thereby increasing the accumulation of these pollutants in fleas. Moreover, Rochman et al. (2014) reported that the coexistence of PS micro(nano)plastics and pollutants could significantly interfere with the endocrine system of adult Oryzias latipe. It is worth mentioning that PS micro(nano)plastics are liable to release polymer monomers, such as styrene monomers, during their degradation and decomposition, which may endowing them the endocrine disruptive effects, such as reducing the reproductive rate (Iguchi et al. 2006). It is worth noting that researchers used extremely high dosage to create negative impacts in their experiments.
The concentrations of microplastics cannot occur in the environment. If micro(nano)plastics are in low contents in the environment, the potential risks remain low too.
Additionally, micro(nano)plastics could impact global diversity due to their function as a biological vector. Micro(nano)plastic particles are rich in organic matter and nutrient due to biofilm formation via adsorbing of organic matter, often performed as the active center for photosynthesis and decomposition, as well as for organic matter and nutrient regeneration (Porter et al. 2018). Micro(nano)plastics could aggregate different types of microorganisms and shift the microbial community structure (Oberbeckmann et al. 2015). The ecological effects may cause gene exchange, invasion of species, spread of pathogenic bacteria, flooding of resistance genes, and the emergence of new species mediated by microorganisms. Moreover, micro(nano)plastics could be also potential vectors for the harmful algae species (Keswani et al. 2016). Once a suitable area is invaded by these species, fulminant propagation will happen under the appropriate physicochemical factors, affecting the physical and chemical properties of bulk water, seriously polluting the marine environment, harming the marine lives, reducing the service function of the ecological environment and ultimately changing biodiversity.

sections.heading: Ways forward
sections.text:
All in all, at the current level, micro(nano)plastics may not cause a significant problem but we must prevent our environment from potential risk. The ecological environment is a closed and intersecting system. Environmental contamination caused by micro(nano)plastics can obviously reduce the service function of the ecological environment. Accordingly, it is urgent that measures needed to be taken to evaluate biodiversity changes caused by micro(nano)plastics in the natural environment. Like atmosphere and water, biodiversity is global, and the existence of micro(nano)plastics is global too. What is the relationship between the two Bglobalities^? The phenomenon requires us to keep more closed collaboration from all countries or regions in the world. What can we do and how to do it? In order to protect global biodiversity, prior to taking action to protect global biodiversity, the following three measures needed to be done: (1) controlling and reducing the sources of micro(nano)plastics into the environment, (2) developing consensus technologies and standard methods for assessing the effect of micro(nano)plastics on biodiversity, (3) focusing on the development of cost-effective clean up and remediation technologies of micro(nano)plastic pollution (Wu et al. 2017). Establishing reliable methods of ecotoxicology and risk assessment of micro(nano)plastics and building policies and regulations in order to prevent biodiversity declining caused by micro(nano)plastics are urgently required,
because the current environmental policies seldom give consideration on micro(nano)plastics. Furthermore, the development of appropriate models would be necessary for assessing and forecasting the impacts of micro(nano)plastics on biodiversity and the interactions between organisms and micro(nano)plastics.

What can we do and how to do it? In order to protect global biodiversity, prior to taking action to protect global biodiversity, the following three measures needed to be done: (1) controlling and reducing the sources of micro(nano)plastics into the environment, (2) developing consensus technologies and standard methods for assessing the effect of micro(nano)plastics on biodiversity, (3) focusing on the development of cost-effective clean up and remediation technologies of micro(nano)plastic pollution (Wu et al. 2017).

metadata.abstractText: Micro(nano)plastics, new emerging contaminants, are ubiquitously found in the environment due to continuous release and accumulation. Widespread micro(nano)plastics can increase their exposure to organisms, pose threats to the ecological environment and human health, and potentially result in global biodiversity changes. Research has been started on micro(nano)plastics regarding their environmental distribution, contamination sources, and methods and technologies for analysis, as well as the environmental impacts and ecological effects on organisms ingesting micro(nano)plastics. However, limited information focused on the consequences of global biodiversity has been reported and the research approaches on biodiversity change caused by micro(nano)plastics are still seldom developed. Recently, researchers in environmental and ecological groups have begun to be conscious of the relationship between micro(nano)plastics and biodiversity. Even so, more efforts are needed to assess the impacts of micro(nano)plastics on this subject, as well as the interactions between organisms and micro(nano)plastics.
